questions.text: A 57 yr old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. He has a history of intake of Amiodarone, Metoprolol, Verapamil, Lisinopril and Amlodipine. During his physical examination, you notice the following discoloration over his face. Which of the following drugs would be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
This is an image of blue grey skin(Ceruloderma), a side effect of Amiodarone.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

Adverse effects of Amiodarone

These are dose-related and increase with duration of therapy.

  • Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on i.v. injection and after drug cumulation.
  • Nausea, gastrointestinal upset may attend oral medication, especially during the loading phase.
  • Photosensitization and sun burn like skin pigmentation occurs in about 10% patients.
  • Corneal microdeposits are common with long term use, may cause headlight dazzle, but are reversible on discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis is the most serious toxicity of prolonged use.

Other options:

Here's a comparison table for Amlodipine, Verapamil, and Metoprolol covering their mechanism of action (MOA), uses, and adverse effects:

choices.text: Inhibition of RNA dependent RNA polymerase
Inhibition of DNA dependent RNA polymerase

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Remdesivir?
questions.solution:
Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a phosphoramidite prodrug of a monophosphate nucleoside analog (GS-441524) and acts as a viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase(RdRp) inhibitor, targeting the viral genome replication process

Here's a table summarizing the different classes of antiviral drugs:

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with ascites due to cirrhosis. The diuretic of choice to reduce edema would be?
questions.solution:
Aldosterone antagonists like Spironolactone and Eplerenone are the drugs of choice for Cirrhotic edema, resistant edema and hypertension.

Uses of Spironolactone & Eplerenone

It is a weak diuretic in its own right and is used mostly in combination with other more efficacious diuretics.

  1. To counteract K+ loss due to thiazide and loop diuretics.
  2. Edema: Spironolactone is more useful in cirrhotic and nephritic edema in which aldosterone levels are generally high. It potentiates thiazides and loop diuretics and is frequently added to them in the treatment of ascites due to cirrhosis of the liver. It breaks resistance to the thiazide/loop diuretic that develops due to secondary hyperaldosteronism and re-establishes the response. Thus, spironolactone is particularly employed in refractory edema.
  3. Hypertension: Spironolactone is used to augment a thiazide in the treatment of resistant hypertension.

questions.text: The dose at which dopamine acts on the β1 receptor is?
questions.solution:
Dopamine has dose dependent actions

Low dose (1-2 mcg/kg/min): It stimulates only D1 receptors leading to renal vasodilation and thus increase in renal blood flow.

Medium dose (2-10 mcg/kg/min): It stimulates both D1 and beta 1 receptors means it will lead to inotropic action also.

High dose (>10 mcg/kg/min): It stimulates D1, beta 1 and alpha 1 receptors resulting in additional vasoconstriction.

questions.text: Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the bioavailability of saquinavir?
questions.solution:
Ritonavir being a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor acts as a booster for other antiretrovirals like Saquinavir.

Ritonavir (RTV)

It is a potent PI; also a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor. Drug interactions, nausea, diarrhoea, paresthesias, fatigue and lipid abnormalities are prominent. Though RTV (600 mg twice daily) can be used as an antiretroviral drug, it is more commonly employed in a low dose (100 mg BD) to boost all other PIs except NFV. Low dose RTV produces no additional side effects.

CYP enzymes inducers & inhibitors

Mnemonic

Enzyme inhibitors[Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indians]

  • Valproate
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cimetidine
  • Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • INH

Enzyme Inducers[GPRS Cell Phone]

  • G - Griseofulvin
  • P - Phenytoin
  • R - Rifampicin
  • S - Smoking
  • Cell - Carbamazepine
  • Phone - Phenobarbitone

questions.text: A patient on warfarin therapy for chronic atrial fibrillation. He was prescribed cephalosporin following a lower respiratory tract infection. He then presents with hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporin is likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
Some cephalosporins owing to the presence of methylthiotetrazole group block Vitamin K epoxide reductase thus causing bleeding as a side effect.

Examples: Cefoperazone, Cefotetan, Cefomandole, Cefmenoxime, Latamoxef.

The also prolong the PT.

Drugs Enhancing anticoagulant action of warfarin

  1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics: inhibit gut flora and reduce vit K production.
  2. Some cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, cefoperazone) cause hypoprothrombinemia by the same mechanism as warfarin-produce additive action.
  3. Aspirin: inhibits platelet aggregation and causes g.i. bleeding-this may be hazardous in anticoagulated patients.
  4. Long acting sulfonamides, indomethacin, phenytoin and probenecid: displace warfarin from plasma protein binding.
  5. Chloramphenicol, erythromycin, celecoxib, cimetidine, allopurinol, amiodarone and metronidazole: inhibit warfarin metabolism.
  6. Tolbutamide and phenytoin: inhibit warfarin metabolism and vice versa.
  7. Liquid paraffin (habitual use): reduces vit K absorption.

choices.text: Drug A increases intestinal absorption of drug B
Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of drug B
Drug A increases metabolism of drug B
Drug A increases renal elimination of drug B

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the table given below
questions.solution:
Area under curve(AUC) denotes the bioavailability of a drug.

In the table, Drug B when given with drug A shows a better bioavailability, which means that Drug A increases absorption and bioavailability of drug B.

Bioavailability

Bioavailability refers to the rate and extent of absorption of a drug from a dosage form administered by any route, as determined by its concentration-time curve in blood or by its excretion in urine.

It is a measure of the fraction (F) of administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in the unchanged form. Bioavailability of drug injected i.v. is 100%, but is frequently lower after oral ingestion because-

(B) The absorbed drug may undergo first pass metabolism in the intestinal wall/liver or be excreted in bile, but since AUC doesn't detect whether active or inactive form of drug reaches bloodstream, the best answer would be A.

(C) Drug A increasing metabolism of drug B would mean a lesser AUC and hence is contradicting.

(D) Drug A increasing renal elimination of drug B is again contradictory as it will then lessen the AUC.

questions.text: A 34 yr old male with hypertension diagnosed with stage 4 chronic kidney disease with eGFR<30 ml/min. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following can be given?
questions.solution:
Metolazone and Indapamide are two thiazide diuretics that can be administered even in patients with renal insufficiency.

Metolazone: In common with loop diuretics, it is able to evoke a clinically useful response even in severe renal failure (g.f.r. ~15 ml/min), and has marked additive action when combined with furosemide. An additional proximal tubular action has been demonstrated; PO4 reabsorption that occurs in PT, is inhibited. It is excreted unchanged in urine. Metolazone has been used mainly for edema.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with epilepsy was put on retigabine TDS. Now phenytoin is being added. Which of the following should be made to retigabine?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin being an enzyme inducer, will stimulate metabolism of Retigabine thus decreasing its bioavailability. Hence, we should increase the dose of Retigabine if given with Phenytoin.

Phenytoin is a potent inducer of CYP2C8/9, CYP3A4/5 isoenzymes. It competitively inhibits CYP2C9/19.

  • Phenobarbitone competitively inhibits phenytoin metabolism, while by enzyme induction both enhance each other's degradation - unpredictable overall interaction.
  • Carbamazepine and phenytoin induce each other's metabolism.
  • Valproate displaces protein bound phenytoin and decreases its metabolism: plasma level of unbound phenytoin increases.
  • Chloramphenicol, isoniazid, cimetidine and warfarin inhibit phenytoin metabolism can precipitate its toxicity.
  • Phenytoin competitively inhibits warfarin metabolism.
  • Phenytoin induces microsomal enzymes and increases degradation of steroids (failure of oral contraceptives), doxycycline, and theophylline.
  • Sucralfate binds phenytoin in g.i. tract and decreases its absorption.

CYP enzymes inducers & inhibitors

Mnemonic

Enzyme inhibitors[Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indians]

  • Valproate
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cimetidine
  • Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • INH

Enzyme Inducers[GPRS Cell Phone]

  • P - Phenytoin

  • S - Smoking

  • Phone - Phenobarbitone

questions.text: A patient with a history of ischemic stroke was started on clopidogrel. However, she had another stroke after 6 months. The most probable reason would be?
questions.solution:
Clopidogrel being a prodrug, is activated by CYP2C19 and hence downregulation of CYP2C19 would lead to failure of Clopidogrel and increased incidence of strokes.

Clopidogrel is a prodrug. About 50% of the ingested dose is absorbed, and only a fraction of this is slowly activated in the liver by two step metabolism into an active thiol metabolite involving CYP2C19, while the rest is inactivated by other enzymes.

Since CYP2C19 exhibits genetic polymorphism, the activation of clopidogrel and consequently its antiplatelet action shows high interindividual variability. Some patients are nonresponsive. Omeprazole, an inhibitor of CYP2C19, reduces metabolic activation of clopidogrel and its antiplatelet action.

The most important adverse effect is bleeding. Addition of aspirin to clopidogrel has been found to double the incidence of serious bleeding among high risk stroke patients.

Metabolism of Drugs

questions.text: Which of the following can be given for long term management of obesity?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide, a GLP-1 agonist causes weight loss as a side effect in diabetics and keeping this in made, it is approved for long term management of obesity.

Another drug for obesity management and is given orally is Semaglutide.

Liraglutide This recently developed longer-acting GLP-1 agonist is closely related to the native peptide but its tight binding to plasma proteins extends t½ to > 12 hours and duration of action to > 24 hours. Injected s.c. once daily, alone or added to oral metformin ± SU or pioglitazone, it has achieved improved glycaemic control in type 2 diabetics.

Nausea and diarrhoea are the frequent side effects, but decrease in incidence over time. Use of liraglutide is attended by weight loss and it is approved for use in obesity.

NOTE: Anti-obesity drugs

Centrally acting anti-obesity drugs: The biologic effect of these agents on appetite regulation is produced by augmentation of the neurotransmission of three monoamines, norepinephrine. serotonin (5-HT) and dopamine.

  • Phentermine - Sympathomimetic (Phentermine is usually used in combination with topiramate)
  • Lorcaserin-Selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist

Peripherally acting medications:

  • Orlistat is a synthetic hydrogenated derivative of a naturally occurring lipase inhibitor, lipostatin, that is produced by the mold Streptomyces toxytricini.

Anti-obesity drugs in development:

  • Bupropion: Dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor
  • Naltrexone: Opioid receptor antagonist

Liraglutide: Glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonist

Note: Tirzepatide is a GIP and GLP-1 agonist recently approved for weight loss treatment.

questions.text: A HIV positive woman who was on ART regimen was treated for migraine. After 4 days she reported with complaints that she is unable to feel her toes for the past 2 days. What might be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Peripheral vascular diseases are a side effect of anti migraine drugs like Triptans and Ergotamine.

Ergotamine

It acts as a partial agonist and antagonist at α adrenergic and all subtypes of 5-HT1 and 5-HT2 receptors, but does not interact with 5-HT3 or dopamine receptors.

Sustained vasoconstriction (because of very slow dissociation from the receptors), visceral smooth muscle contraction, vasomotor centre depression are produced, and the action of NA and 5-HT on smooth muscles is antagonized.

At high doses CNS stimulation and paresthesias may be experienced.

On chronic exposure (ergot poisoning) vasoconstriction is accompanied by damage to capillary endothelium resulting in thrombosis, vascular stasis and gangrene.

questions.text: Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor approved for
questions.solution:
Immune checkpoint inhibitors: James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo received Nobel prize in physiology or medicine for their discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation. Normally, there are certain checkpoints, so that immune cells (like T-cells) do not attack self antigens. Certain receptors like PD-1 (programmed death receptors) or CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein) are present on T-cells. When ligands on other cells (PDL-1 or CD-80/86 respectively) bind to these receptors, T-cells are inhibited. Same method is utilized by some cancer cells to evade destruction from T-cells. These tumor cells overexpress the ligands like PDL-1 and inhibit T-cells. Monoclonal antibodies targeting these interactions result in disinhibition of these brakes and thus, T-cells can destroy cancer cells.

(a) PD-1 and PDL-1 inhibitors

  • Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and Cemiplimab are monoclonal antibodies against PD-1 receptors on T-cells.
  • Atezolizumab, Avelumab and Durvalumab are monoclonal antibodies against PDL-1 present on cancer cells.

(b) CTLA-4 Inhibitor:

Normally CD-80 or CD-86 present on antigen presenting cells bind to CD-28 present on T-cells. Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte Antigen-4 (CTLA-4) is a CD-28 homologue expressed on T-cells. Binding of this with CD-80/86 molecules inhibit the T-cells. Ipilimumab acts as CTLA-4 inhibitor resulting in T-cell activation and destruction of cancer cells. It is approved for treatment of malignant melanoma.

questions.text: Paradoxical bronchoconstriction seen with ipratropium bromide is due to all except
questions.solution:
Reports of paradoxical bronchoconstriction with ipratropium bromide, particularly when given by nebulizer, were largely explained as effects of the hypotonic nebulizer solution and by antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

This problem has not been described with tiotropium bromide or other LAMAs. Occasionally, bronchoconstriction may occur with ipratropium bromide given by MDI. It is possible that this is due to blockade of prejunctional M2 receptors on airway cholinergic nerves that normally inhibit ACh release.
